title: The J. William Holland Memorial Lecture: Men of Bronze—How Greek Hoplite Warriors Transformed the Ancient World
hero_caption: Attributed to the Painter of Berlin 1686 or the Painter of Tarquinia RC 3984. Belly-Amphora (Storage Jar), about 550/540 BC. Athens, Greece. Katherine K. Adler Memorial Fund.
short_description: John Hale presents the epic story of the Greek hoplite tradition.
description:
Among the glories of Classical Greece were the hoplites, citizen-soldiers who guaranteed the defense of their cities. Named for the words for their shields and other bronze gear, these soldiers ultimately gave us a tradition of government by citizen assemblies, since only those who served their communities in warfare could be awarded full voting rights or hold public office. In this illustrated lecture, John Hale, professor and director of the Liberal Studies Program at the University of Louisville, presents the epic story of the Greek hoplite tradition and recounts his archaeological quest to recover hoplite weapons and other objects from Greek battles on land and sea.
